text.body:
<div type="letter”> Aug. 5, 1916. Dear Harriet:
Of course I will let you wait a little while before paying me for "1777," but your sum of $45.00 is a little surprise to me, as I thought it was $60.00, although I see that $60.00 would be more than the pages come to. I have not my files up here, but I thought that when you were to print "The Turnpike," you were to give me $75.00, and that when I changed from "the Turnpike" to "1777" at your desire, I objected to the fact that I was to lose money; but you said you could not give me more than $60.00. At your regular rates, "1777" would come to $56.00. If, however, you are quite sure that $45.00 is what you agreed to pay, we will let it go at that. I think the poem looks very well.
Who is Mr. Victor Starbuck? For I especially like his lyric, and I think I shall write him a letter, in care of you, and tell him so.
I am glad you like the "Flashlights" review. Of course, put my name at the end. I sort of assumed that you would, which is the reason it was not on the manuscript.</p
I am glad you are going to leave out "The Painter on Silk" for theAnthology, and substitute either "Chinoiseries" or "The Captured Goddess." As between these two, I think perhaps "The Captured Goddess" would be the better understood and the more popular, although I am especially fond of "Chinoiseries" myself. So you see, I have no preference and will leave to you. I understand that my group now stands: "Patterns" "1777" "Venus Transiens"
"A Lady" "Chinoiseries" or "The Captured Goddess" "Solitaire" "A Gift" "Red Slippers" "Apology"
I still maintain that "Malmaison" in the August "Little Review" is the best poem I have written, although possibly it is too long for you, although I believe Braithwaite is to use it in his Magazine Anthology. However, I am quite pleased with the group as it stands. Affectionately yours,
